name: Texas Capitol
reviews: Great treasure that belongs to the citizens of Texas. There is so much to see and everyone who visits should take their time. My recommendation is to take the 30-minute guided tour first and then go on a self-guided tour just so that you get a little more background on the capital building. There is a basement that has a whole other section and if you visit Monday through Friday you can actually eat at the capital grille which has excellent prices on food. There's a lot of history in the capital and there are photos that explain the restoration, how the capital was restored back to its original beauty, and also highlights the history of the first Capitol building. Don't be surprised if you go and there is a concert on the first floor of the rotunda. The acoustics are fabulous. The exterior grounds are equally as interesting. There are cannons from world war II era and there is a mural that highlights important people in Texas history. A great place and I can't wait to visit again

Absolutely stunning. The details throughout the entire building all have meaning - you can truly spend at least half a day just roaming the halls and examining the various portraits, paintings, light fixtures, etc  and learning their importance to Texas state history. 

While we did a self-guided tour, I highly recommend taking a guided tour so you can hear more about the stories and meaning behind the many treasures of the capital.

If you enjoy history, and have some time it's a nice location to wander. The grounds are clean with fabulous views of downtown, not to mention the capital is beautiful! The craftsmanship of the builders is on full display and the structure is well maintained. Gawking in the center of the rotunda never gets old 😂🤣

Do You Have What It Takes?

My wife and I visited the Texas State Capitol Building in May.

As we were neared the main entrance we were greeted by a man on an electric wheelchair wearing a red "MAGA" hat brandishing a Confederate flag next to a sign that read  "Remember The Alamo".

It was at this moment we thought to ourselves, "do we have what it takes?"

"Are we, one Northerner and one Brazilian, worthy of entering the State Capitol of Texas?"

As we neared closer the the entrance the man on the electric wheelchair seemed to stare straight into the depths of my soul. 

What was he looking for?

Could he tell I was born north of the Mason-Dixie line?

What should I do?

As these thoughts raced through my Midwestern mind the man turned his gaze to a woman crossing the main path.

His turning gaze gave us the window of opportunity we needed to pass by, undetected, into the main entrance where we seamlessly slipped in to an ongoing public tour.

Beautiful grounds and building.  Great history to be seen. Start in Treasury Office and see a photo of the Texas currency prior to it becoming a State.  Grab a self guide tour pamphlet or join a guided tour for in depth info.  For a little bit of fun trivia grab a scavenger hunt page and enjoy!  The fourth floor Bonus question was our favorite!  The grounds are full of monuments celebrating the rich history of Texas contributions to our country.  It also memorializes a time that challenged this Nation with the struggle of States Rights.  The largest of any Capitol building in the entire U.S. including the U.S. Capitol.  Definitely worth a visit, and yes it is made from granite (TX red granite).

name: The Escape Game Austin
address: 405 Red River St, Austin, TX 78701, USA
reviews: We played The Heist, it was challenging and satisfying to solve! We asked that our game be paced and we used our three clues. Which were perfect clues. They just gave us another piece of the puzzle but didn’t solve the games for us. The puzzles were unique and impressive. They had some show stopper puzzles. We solved in with 7 minutes left and were so excited. I would definitely recommend this place! We were also impressed with staff member Anessa! She was very knowledgeable, gave the perfect hints, and had good high energy!

This place was well worth it. It was 4 of us added another couple whom we didn't know. However we all worked to find clues and figure out puzzles. At the end of the day we all had a great time and would for sure be going back sometime soon. I would recommend as they have a few different options to choose from as well.

awesome place!!! staff is really amazing & friendly. they don’t judge and make you feel welcomed! thank you for having us. i definitely recommend anyone to stop by and have a little fun there’s a few games to pick from all seem like fun but gold rush is my favorite! i will for sure come back.

Great overall experience!  My wife and I have done almost 30 escape rooms.  This is one of our favorites.  Booking was easy.  When we arrived we were promptly greeted and shown waivers to sign.  The greeter was pleasant and friendly.  The lobby was clean and well kept.  The game started on time (always a plus).  We did Prison break.  Super fun room.  Immersive decor and atmosphere throughout.  The puzzles were challenging but we never got "stuck", thanks to some well timed and welcomed hints.  The game host was attentive and enthusiastic.  We escaped with time to spare and will be back this week for another room.  If you're in the area you should definitely check them out, whether you are a veteran of escape rooms or have never done one before.  This would be a great choice for any experience level.

This was such a amazing team building experience. Even though we didn’t find everything we still made it out with 39 seconds on the clock. Highly recommend to any teens or adults that want to get closer as a group!

name: Barton Springs Municipal Pool
address: 2131 William Barton Dr, Austin, TX 78746, USA
reviews: Great spot but you really can only enjoy it during the winter months when it's not crowded by the local UT hooligans or the California state jumpers. I've mostly have had to go by the Colorado River part and take a dip or two while avoiding every dog in Austin with their camel Joe looking family. Some of the homeless people will offer to rub sun lotion on you free of charge which is cool.

We didn't go into Barton Springs since it was too cold, but it looked amazing! The water was so clean and calm especially at night time. Also the view was spectacular. I can't believe it's free as well! If the weather was warmer, this looks like the place to be.
Love taking the kids here.  The water is always so nice and cool.  The bathrooms are clean and the crowd is typically very friendly.  Worth the drive up from San Antonio any weekend!
This place is a great place to relax and take a dip. It was a bit cold in February but still was a good time. It’s cool to see the mix of natural and man made features in the pool

This was fun, there's a free side and there's also a side where you pay. The side where you pay is more like a giant pool with natural water in it versus chlorinated pool water. The free side is on the other side of the fenced area and is more natural. You got to get there early to be able to get a parking space though.

name: Bullock Texas State History Museum
reviews: LOVE THIS PLACE..... the exhibits are FRESH, thoughtful, innovative and enriching.  They give me insight about culture and context historically I didn't know I wanted or needed making time and place more real than I could have imagined!
The staff is amazing. Beautiful museum and if the movies going to be awesome in 3D then you need to see it here. Avatar 3D here was by far the most impressive thing I've seen to this day.

If you are a long time resident of Texas or new to the state or just visiting I highly recommend going to the Bullock! Tells the story of Texas,  Mexico and the Southern states very well with good documentation. Story starts in prehistory all the way through modern times. Also has a IMAX theater that shows all kind of movies. Also has traveling exhibits. Well worth the visit,  more than once!

It is a good place to spend few hours learning about Texas history.  However  they have plenty of space there and I think they can do a better job at selecting more interesting artifacts/aspects of US/Texas history. The place feels empty in some spots and you go  home without too many things to remember.

The Bullock Texas State History Museum (often referred to as the Bob Bullock Texas State History Museum or Bullock Museum), is a history museum in Austin, Texas. The museum, located a few blocks north of the Texas State Capitol at 1800 North Congress Avenue in Austin, Texas, is dedicated to interpreting the continually unfolding "Story of Texas" to the broadest possible audience through meaningful educational experiences. The museum is operated by the Texas State Preservation Board, which also operates the Texas State Capitol, the Texas Capitol Visitors Center, the Texas Governor's Mansion, and the Texas State Cemetery.

The Bullock Texas State History Museum is named after the 38th Lieutenant Governor of Texas Bob Bullock, who championed the preservation and exhibition of Texas history and worked to establish its creation. Bullock was the guest of honor at the groundbreaking ceremony for the museum in April 1999 and died the following June before the museum was completed.

name: McKinney Falls State Park
address: 5808 McKinney Falls Pkwy, Austin, TX 78744, USA
reviews:
Wonderful place to visit.  Great hikes, fun swimming.  This is a favorite place to camp.

I would strongly recommend anyone park at the upper or lower falls, visit that falls, then do a round trip hike to the other falls.  It's not a challenging hike at all, but it is pretty and interesting... Especially in the spring.

Nice park 15 minutes outside of downtown Austin.  It’s not removed enough to totally block out the cacophony street traffic and construction, but it’s muted enough to enjoy your surroundings.  There’s a surprising amount of trail miles here that wonder along river banks, meadows and tranquil forest as well as past some historical sites (and the oldest tree in the state!).  The park serves as a nice, welcome escape from the bustle of the city and close enough there’s no excuse not to go.

Great area to hike. Trails are paved, but have hills and turns to keep you challenged. Easy to moderate level of walking/hiking. We only did one trail, which was 2.8 miles. Would like to do them all. Then combine them for a longer day hike!

Great state park close to town (Austin) to go relax, go on a nice hike, and only $6 when it was just me. Good swimming spots too, and one of the trails takes you to a historical house. Great to pack a back pack w small supplies if a long hike but I also saw someone with not much on a run.

A beautiful park to visit. Enormous, lovely Cypress trees along the river banks, nice trails, and of course the falls and swimming area. There is an entrance fee. We paid $10 so I'm not sure if it was $5 each or $10 per car. They do accept credit cards and dogs are allowed (on leash).

name: Zilker Botanical Garden
address: 2220 Barton Springs Rd, Austin, TX 78746, USA
reviews: The layout of the gardens is great because you can make sure you see everything without back tracking through what you've already explored. Not that it would be horrible, it's a garden so it's gorgeous. It is still winter (late February early March), so not everything is beautiful and blooming. So I won't fault Zilker for that, but I do hope they go around the grounds and update all their bee/bug homes (forgot to get a photo). They're pretty run down and look like they haven't been touched on a while. I also wish they had more butterfly and bird houses on the grounds. They have a butterfly garden, but due to the time of year, we didn't see any. But I also didn't see any butterfly homes for them to rest in. There was also an orchid show going on whole we were there, so that was a nice surprise. Great place for families and a great experience for kids to learn about the flora and fauna.

Went in the middle of winter (still a beautiful day), so there wasn’t much color around.  Regardless, a great stroll in a peaceful quiet.
Was there on a weekday, at about noon, and there were about 5-10 other parties throughout the grounds, so I didn’t really run into others.
It is larger than you see at first glance.  Has some nice areas to sit for a picnic, photo shoots, and relax.
Only been to a handful of botanical gardens before, but compared to those others, this one is still on the small side, and not very elaborate.

Very nice place. Lots to look at. Beautiful place to take pictures.  We saw one couple taking wedding photos , one couple got engaged in front of the waterfall and many others taking their graduation photos. Beautiful plants and calming walk. A must to see.

Some of the best gardens I have ever visited. There is something for everyone there, kids, adults.. old, young.... Such an amazing place to enjoy in Austin! The azaleas are magnificent in spring and the grounds are meticulously groomed.
Highly recommended for everyone. An oasis of beauty and tranquility.

I took my kids (4 and 1.5) here and they really enjoyed exploring the trails. The air is so sweet and the views of the foliage are wonderful. The Japanese section was particularly nice. Great place to relax and let the kids explore. Will be back.

name: Circuit of the Americas
address: 9201 Circuit of the Americas Blvd, Austin, TX 78617, USA
reviews: Awesome place. Went here to see some GT racing and had a blast. A lot of walking but very worth it. Restrooms are very clean with sensor soap and water so you don't have to touch anything to wash hands. They have food and drinks and they range from 6-12$. You can bring lawn chairs and walk anywhere on the property to sit and watch the race. If you love racing and motors, you'll enjoy this place. Highly recommend and will definitely come again.

My wife and I came here for a vacation this year and it was absolutely amazing. The weather wasn't overly cooperative but it was February after all. The event staff was more than helpful and always willing to point you in the right direction. Surprisingly the food and the merchandise was not over prices like my wife thought it would be. We will absolutely be going here again for more races.

Great family fun place! Saw a little bit of F1 Race Cars practicing.  The Kart track racing was awesome! 55mph in a Kart was incredible! Very nice people in general! Check it out if you are near the airport!

Was here for Fully Charged Live event focusing on electric vehicles. It was a great place for a large event. The facilities here are very nice and lots of room for a big show. Would be nice if they had a few larger secondary rooms, at this event the 2nd stage area was packed tight. But may be because the speakers were so good.

We went to the electric car show held here. We tried the cafe that is there. It is a deli style cafe that also sells burgers and fries. It was fresh food and great fries. The staff are friendly and kept the place clean. I did see some people confounded a bit on which was compostable trash and recyclable. Maybe a small picture guide to help? The indoor restrooms are always a plus in Texas! The restrooms were kept clean, a huge plus! The event setup indoors did have good sound control - no resounding echos or cross presenters competing with traveling sound. That is probably helpful since the F-1 track was in use that day. We could hear the track but it was muffled background noise that we were fine with.

name: Barton Creek Greenbelt
address: 3755 S Capital of Texas Hwy B, Austin, TX 78704, USA
reviews: Can get busy fast so arrive early.   We arrived at 8 am and there were not many people.  When we left around 11:45 the entire parking lot was full.  Good shaded area for hiking with your pets or alone.  The hike is very easy so anyone could do it.   Nice place to visit within the city.

Nice place for a long, but fairly flat hike.  I went on a weekday in December at about noon and it was pretty empty.  Decently peaceful, though you’ll have to go to about the mile and a half mark to completely get away from the traffic sounds of Mopac.
Not much color nor water when I went, though I imagine the creek gets to be beautiful at the right time of the year.

Austin is an amazing city, growing so fast the city and roads can't keep up. 
 There is no real public transportation to most of the city.  Traffic is everywhere. At the heart of this buzzing, growing city, the Barton Creek Greenbelt stands as a work of such visionary genius it seems to make up for everything else!  Escape into woods and streams and rivers and dry creeks.  Walk for miles - days if you like.  Rock climb.   Be in nature - its right through the heart of town.  Central Park gets all the attention but the Barton Creek Greenbelt captures the real magic of beauty and power of nature.  Take a trip there on a beautiful winter day (65 degrees and sunny). It may just change your life.

Beautiful trees and trail but it is far too over used!!! We don't have enough nature to enjoy for the 1M peeps of Austin. Go and enjoy, but tread lightly, be respectful, and don't my leave litter. 

If you haven't heard we're in a Climate Crisis that we started. We're spray billion year old dead plants into the air like The Night King raised the dead at Winterfell. What are we doing? What are you doing?  Why aren't we taking this seriously!?! Our jobs and status are not worth an extinction.

I went there about three times for a research project for Planet Earth, and I personally enjoyed my time there. I would definitely recommend visiting there for fresh air or if you need some green for refresher. There wasn’t any water present when I visited due to fluctuation of water, so make sure to check the water status of the creek.

Have a nice day!

name: Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center
address: 4801 La Crosse Ave, Austin, TX 78739, USA
reviews: Wonderful place to walk around and let kids play in big green grass area.  You can bring food in. It is wonderful for a picnic.  The flowers are wonderful.  Only neg... Parking can be limited if it is a busy day.      It is not easy to walk through during mid day in the Summer. They do offer extended hours in the evening on particular days.

We love botanical gardens and this was one of the best. Worth the $12 entry for an adult. Walking trails were very easy. Lots of family play areas and picnic areas. Native Texas flowers were coming into bloom. Bluebonnets! Gift store was nice. Tours available and free. Easy to get to and entry of parking on a cloudy rainless weekday.

We came in March and it was a beautiful cloudy cool day. Lots of things were in bloom, like the grape-smelling Texas Mountain Laurel and bluebonnets. So wonderful! Many things will bloom later and it would be worth another trip next month.

This place was so charming and wonderful. It ended up being a perfect day to go walking around this wonderful place. Everything was so beautifully maintained, and the staff was so nice and friendly. Can't wait to go back in the summer when more wildflowers have bloomed.

I never knew about this park. The exhibits were awesome during Fortlandia, great family fun and the park is so spacious and beautiful it’s easy to have a wonderful time with the little ones. The last exhibit was, build your own fort. Which my son and did not hesitate to do.

name: Thinkery
reviews: The Thinkery is a great experience for anyone who has children that love to explore. The exhibits have very little explanation which motivates you to have those cherished moment with your kids to figure it out. Leading them to use their minds, and create in a way they may not be accustomed to. If you have a day off, and want something new to do then stop on by. You will not regret your experience, and neither will your children.

Awesome hands on place for the kids. They have a blast with all the interactive exhibits. My son love the tech take apart area and my daughter loves the painting wall. There are so many areas to keep the kids busy and active. The playground next door is also amazing. Membership is very reasonable for the year and well worth it.

Great place for kids and adults! Lots of fun things to check out. The price $14 is well worth it! Only complaint is the process they take for adults without kids that want to come In and explore. Kinda awkward, they keep your ID and make you sign something. Great for keeping kids “safe” I guess but kinda uncomfortable if you just want to check out the inside. I felt like I learned more things from this  museum then I do with most museums! Info on plaques is easy to comprehend and super educational! I really loved this place but prob won’t be back since I don’t have a child to take in with me. But over all this place is so fun and interactive for the whole family!

great place for young kids. There is plenty to do plenty to explore and plenty to learn at this facility. This is a great hidden gem that everyone visiting Austin should try to visit if they have children under the age of 12. There's an outdoor facility that really helps with them in their motor skills and figuring out how to maneuver obstacles. There are healthy snacks available. There are several areas for kids to explore different aspects of life and help them with their cognitive thinking and motor skills. Currently the cost is $14 per person for all over the age of two. The ticket is good for an entire day's visit and it's very well worth it.

The Thinkery was absolutely awesome.   Went with the whole second grade from the school I work at.  I was so surprised at how much there was to do.  Our students had so much fun that I wish we would have been able to spend more than just two hours there.  The staff was really friendly starting with the lady that gave our students the speech on where to go and how to act inside.  She made it fun and very kid friendly.

name: Mayfield Park and Nature Preserve
reviews: when I lived in the area this was one of my favorite places to visit. The tranquility, the peacefulness,  the ponds with the koi fish, and all of the flowers make this a place that you can just sit and stay for hours. The peacocks are in the trees they're on the house they're on the grounds and some of them can be quite friendly and come right up to you. it's a great place to take kids it's a great place to just walk around and take pictures of flowers. I have several pictures of the flowers and peacocks that I've taken over the years and I've given them as gifts and people treasure them.

This place was absolutely breathtaking. I felt so in tune with the atmosphere around me. The peacocks  were stunning. Thank you for this wonderful experience. It was the perfect send off back to Michigan.

The best time of year to visit this park is definitely in the spring since the garden has gorgeous flowers in bloom. That said, while the park grounds were undergoing some restoration and thus looked a little sad compared with their typical state (including a couple of the fish in the pond that I'm pretty sure were dead), the peacocks still seemed happy to roam the grounds and roost in the trees, and the preserve trail was gorgeous with the tail end of fall leaves adding bright red and orange here and there. I can only imagine what the park looked like a few weeks ago, and if I manage to visit next fall I'll bet that will turn out to be my other favorite time of year to visit.

My life is accomplished after getting to see so many beautiful peacocks and peahens from such a short distance. And who knew peacocks sit on tree branches! A must go, at least once. The park is free and not so very crowded. You can spend 30 minutes and leave with content eyes!

The Mayfield Park and Nature Preserve is a very beautiful park to visit. There are a few small trails in the back right part of the park that loop around the parking lot making it very difficult to get lost. The garden was also very lovely the only complaint I have would be that the flowers were not labeled by their name rather by the volunteers names so I had no idea what type of flowers I was looking at. There was also a coipond that had many fish in it and a few peacocks that were roaming around. There were a lot of great places for a photo opportunity. In addition for the trails I would recommend comfortable shoes because it can get rocky at some points.

name: Ann W. Richards Congress Avenue Bridge
reviews: Even though it was too early for the bats, this is a gorgeous walk. The parks along the banks of the river offer several activities including rowing. Lots of photo opportunities, including this little overhang off the walkway. The area is very clean - cleaner than I thought it would be. I would come back often if I lived there.

It's a bridge. It conveys cars and pedestrians. There are trails underneath. Sometimes, I'm told, there are bats, but none were to be seen in early March. But it's a very effective bridge. Maybe not the most attractive bridge in the world. But a bridge nonetheless.

Overall, I honestly think it was an 6-7/10 bridge and I'll tell you it lost points for lack of flair or style. I'm going to give it 5 stars for the Google review though because it did its job well and it's really my fault for coming to Austin so early in bat season when you think about it. I'll re-review next time we're here.

Again, good bridge.

Here to watch the bats. Pretty amazing! The bridge alone is great but I'm sorry, too many homeless laying around the streets and asking for handouts. Kind of scary for families wanting to walk around without fear.

Those pesky bats haven't been trained very well! They were late and flew out on the wrong side of the bridge...... actually very nice views in the area, well taken care of area and a good sized crowd the day I went. Would recommend going to see if you"re in the area, be prepared to wait, since the bats  still need training, but they will come out.

Went across this bridge for regular sports of transportation around Austin. While walking across early evening I saw the extraordinary sight of the bats flying out from under the bridge in order to go eat for the night. I had never seen anything like it. It was quite incredible.

name: Austin Aquarium
reviews:
Amazing place for Kids and Adults. This place is a little on the smaller side, but it more than makes up for it with its interactive exhibits and range of exotic animals. Want to hold an exotic bird on your wrist? Pet a stingray? Or have a pair of lemurs run across your shoulders? This place has it all.

Make sure to research their 'Token' system, as this is about 1/2 the cost of the attraction. These let you feed animals and get into the more expensive 'interactive experiences'.

There is a wide array of animals, so the fact that this place is called an aquarium is more of a technicality. Fish, Birds, Reptiles, and even an Octopus!

There's even a play area and other fun surprises that will leave a lasting impression for those visiting with young ones. Definitely a great weekend activity for anyone who enjoys animals

Excellent place, tons of fun for kids. To fully enjoy the experience you have to buy quite a few tokens.  One of the managers Alex was super helpful. And very knowledgeable. He Brought out a snake for kids to see and hold.  He made the experience awesome! The best experience was the lemur encounter.  Kids loved feeding the stingrays as well.

This place is spectacular when it comes to entertaining your children. The reptiles, birds, monkeys, and all the interactive activities is amazing. Make sure to have your children have shoes on otherwise they cant enter the activity areas. Overall loved it and would ho back a 100 more times if I could.

This place exceeded my expectations beyond belief. It was amazing. Yes, it's smaller than most aquariums but the amount of interactions can't be beat. They say when you walk in and get ready to start that "if you can reach the animals, you can touch the animals..." That pretty much describes the experience. Hands down loved it.

All of the animals here are extremely healthy and active! Great for both kids and adults. It’s in a shopping plaza and it looks more child-friendly on the outside but once you get inside it’s honestly one of the best aquariums I’ve ever been to!

name: Covert Park at Mount Bonnell
address: 3800 Mt Bonnell Rd, Austin, TX 78731, USA
reviews: Lots of fun with nice views of the river and the city skyline. It is a disappointingly short/easy hike; you'll get to the top in about 10 minutes or so. Still, a pleasant visit especially with friends or family and food in tow. I'd recommend you find some other activity to pair with it since this doesn't take much time at all.
Wonderful views of the Texas Hill country right outside of Austin! Also,a good place to take people from out of town to show them Austin. It's nice to see the fancy homes too.

Mount Bonnell is an iconic Austin view I adore to share. It's definitely a destination for out-of-town visitors or locals who have never seen it need to be taken there. Beautiful view. Amazing sunsets. Also gorgeous in the morning when it is quieter. I have visited many times since a child and ensure others are able to enjoy it also.
This was our first time here. The view is amazing. Well worth the small climb up the stairs. Awsome photo ops too!
Great view and wonderful vibes. Came here after a work camping trip with the crew to enjoy our return home to Austin. Took some time to enjoy the park and the skyline of our home town

name: Blanton Museum of Art
address: 200 E Martin Luther King Jr Blvd, Austin, TX 78712, USA
reviews: A beautiful museum, though small, shows off a wonderful variety of pieces. From American to European, to Latin America and more, the art on display are delightfully thought provoking some even being interactive. The gift shop/cafe was also very nice. I recommend if you have time, or are showing a friend around who enjoys art museums to give this one a shot. It's very clean, organized, and the staff are polite. It's a very pleasant experience overall.

This was an interesting museum. A must visit if you are into arts! It's got arts of all kind(classical paintings to sculptures, modern to abstract kinda). This place also has a building that is also an art installation. Pretty cool place to walk around and appreciate classic works of art. Plus, you get free access if you're a student at any University of Texas campuses. Just have your I'd on you.

This museum is absolutely beautiful. There is artwork from multiple time periods and genres. Overall there is a really great collection. The museum is clean and very open and spacious. I would definitely recommend going if you are ever in the Austin area.

The Blanton has a great permanent collection of art from various eras and styles, as well as excellent rotating galleries and pieces. The permanent pieces bear repeated contemplation, and the museum is free (as of this review's writing) every Thursday courtesy of the Moody Foundation! It's also open late every third Thursday of the month.

The museum validates parking in the garage next door for a very affordable rate, so it's easy to stay as long as you like!

It is conveniently located close to where I was staying @ AT&T Convention Center hotel. There's a museum and a separate Cafe & Gift shop. The little Meditation building on-site is stunning. Inside the museum, ($12 per ticket) the architecture is very appealing and several comprehensive exhibits, all well displayed by subject, type of media, or date. 
Highly recommend.

name: LBJ Presidential Library
address: 2313 Red River St, Austin, TX 78705, USA
reviews: Architecture of the building is amazing. Inside has a great atmosphere, as it is a large open atrium at one point. My favorite idea of the museum is that it relates bills signed into law into how they affect current everyday life. They could provide more detail, but it is something I've not seen in other Presidential museums. The oval office is neat, and NASA is a personal favorite of mine, so it was awesome seeing a moon rock, and learning that LBJ sponsored the legislation in the Senate and President Eisenhower signed the law creating NASA. This is one of the better Presidential museums!

A must for those who remember the 60's, although all of LBJ''s life is represented. This was a complex man, despite his aura of unflappable stability. Many items displayed from familial, state capitol and White House stock. Ease of layout means free-flowing viewing without a need to double-back or divert direction erratically.. The museum's planners deserve an 'A' for effort and accomplishment. A 'must see' in Austin.

My 60's era President. Introduced a passed monumental legislation. Got the job done. Vietnam did him in though.  He was truly a force of nature. Museum is very well done.
.

The LBJ Library is a great experience. Seeing all the president's papers as you go up the grans staircase is inspiring. The exhibits are rotated frequently enough so it doesn't get stale.  If you are a total wonk, make an appointment to go through the archives. When done enjoy the great lawn outside the library and maybe take a stroll on campus.

The LBJ Library is a thoughtfully engaging museum incorporating not only the incredible accomplishments of President Johnson and Lady Bird, but the state of the world during the 1960's. From 5,000 hours of phone conversations to 45 million pages of historic documents, this museum gives in depth insight into the presidency of Lyndon B Johnson, as a president, family man, and social worker. There are plenty of interactive exhibits, videos, letters, and photos to keep you entertained throughout the three floors of the museum, finishing with the Oval office replica on the 10th floor.

name: Walking Tours of Austin
reviews:
We really enjoyed our morning walk tour with Jim! He shared many small tidbits and facts that made the experience very interesting. He also took the time to answer individual questions we had. And we could feel his passion and love for Austin! We highly recommend this tour with Jim if you want to learn about Austin history in a short and easy walking tour.

-Che & Munjuli

I took this tour last night with some friends that were visiting and we all loved it. Jim has great energy and is an excellent storyteller/historian. His knowledge and passion for the stories he told was infectious. Definitely recommend taking his tour!!

Jim was FANTASTIC, very knowledgeable and passionate. We throughly enjoyed our ghost walk tour and would encourage all to make it part of their Austin experience. We would definitely do another one of his offered tours. Thank You!
- Chicago family
Great tour with interesting stories told very well by Jim.  He was a great guide and it was definitely a different way to experience and learn about Austin that we enjoyed very much! Thanks Jim!
This was a fun tour that touched on Austin history, supernatural hauntings, and a serial killer! Not a bad walk at all. Our tour guides were enthusiastic and kept the crowd's attention.

name: Greetings From Austin Mural
reviews: Huge iconic mural in south Austin. Make sure you go inside of Road House Relics to see some other cool stuff and get some really neat Austin souvenirs, and maybe even get the chance to meet the famous Todd Sanders!

This mural in Austin is so vibrant and looks exactly like the picture. It is the perfect place to tale some touristy pictures and there was great lighting in front of the mural. You also do not need to step that far back to get the whole picture in the frame which is good. I would definitely recommend visiting this mural if you ever visit Austin.

A very beautiful and well preserved mural. It is too easy to spot as it always looks bit crowded. We had to wait to get  in to take photos. This is directly on the road , because of which it also affects the traffic because many tourist literally stand center on the road to click pictures in different angle. The road is a busy one.
Great place to take a picture if visiting Austin. Generally not too busy so you can get a quick photo and leave. A lot of restaurants and shops nearby too.

So so so easy to find. It’s actually downtown on the side of a business. I thought it would be on the highway as you enter. I was able to take lots of photos and other people were willing to help. But you do need to stand in the street or across the street to get the whole painting in the photo.

name: Pennybacker Bridge
address: 5300 N Capital of Texas Hwy, Austin, TX 78730, USA
reviews: There’s a small trail to climb up a hilltop where visitors are allowed to see the magnificent bridge and the lake overview. Parking is on the side of the road and free but may get busy with lot of visitors. Kids have to be little carefully as there is no ropes to safeguard them. The hike itself is not that complicated and can have fun time on the hilltop.

360 view point and you can get a view of Austin downtown near to the bridge. The bridge gives an iconic prestige view to the Austin area. You can enjoy the evening sunset over the bridge and it gives elegance feeling.

Beautiful Bridge in Austin. Great place to relax and enjoy the sunset. Also great outdoor for some photo ops. There is a little hike but the view is worth it. Bridge, Colorado River, Boats and Sunsets gives a perfect composition.

Great place to bring family and friends visiting from out of town. The view is amazing! Make sure you wear sneakers and are able to climb up the slippery rocks. My mother had difficulty getting up to the top. If your visiting Austin be sure to stop here!
Beautiful trail! Views of the river, bridge and lots of green. Easy hike that turns into narrow path

name: Peter Pan Mini-Golf
address: 1207 Barton Springs Rd, Austin, TX 78704, USA
reviews: 7 bucks a person (cash only), and I definitely think it's worth it if you have a couple of friends you want to bring along. There are only two courses, and each took my friends and me about an hour and a half for each. They're open late, so it's good for evening golfing. Some of the sculptures for the holes are... interesting to say the least. You can tell the artwork is more in line with the art styles of when the place opened (1948!), but they're well made and stand for a good laugh/photo shoot. The only thing I didn't like was the assortment of empty/half full beer bottles along the sides of some of the courses. They weren't in the way, but it would be nice to have seen a little bit of cleaning up, although we might have just come at a bad time, it was a Saturday night after all so who knows. Overall, even though the place is a little old there's lots of fun to be had at Peter Pan Mini-Golf, definitely would go again!

This was a fun place.  It was great to experience a small part of Austin's history.  It was nice to see the history articles at the end of the West course too.  I will say though that although I enjoyed it this was probably the worst mini golf course I've even been to.  I get that it's old but the greens were covered in leaves and debris, the cement was in a state of disrepair, the carpet needs replaced where it's worn thin, and the night lighting is so bad you can't see all the deformities in the cement under the greens.  Needs some pretty extensive maintenance and walkway lighting to help with the shadows but overall I'm glad I finally did it.

Although this place is quite old and seems rather run-down, still there were a lot of people around, and my 7 year old daughter really had a great time. The décor is rather interesting. They have two courses, and you will have to pay per course, only by cash. Parking can be a bit of a problem. It’s a good way to spend an hour or two with kids.

Great afternoon activity for a group. Make sure you bring cash (cash only) and ask at the front which of the two sets of holes is less busy. BYOB with lots of kitschy statues on the holes so you know it’s gonna be a good time.

VERY crowded, but everyone moved right along. Pretty nice courses and reasonably priced at $7 per person with an additional 18 holes for only $4 more.

The only negative I have is that the greens should be swept/vacuumed a little better than they've been doing it.

name: Museum of the Weird
reviews: Super fun. An eclectic collection of oddities. Some taxidermy of mutant farm animals, neat wax statues from movies and such, and a fun side show. Guy with a three legged dog gave us a great show. We were lucky to have him as a guide too.  We got some stuff from the store front. Worth checking out in smaller groups.

Nothing super weird about it, but enjoyable nonetheless. I took my 9 year old daughter and she said the best part was the special show at the end. I agreed. It is a small "museum" in the back of a gift shop and I personally think the admission is too high for what you get. This is best for kids and those who don't generally know about weird and unusual things or oddities (like me).

Definitely worth a visit. We took our toddler daughter with us and she enjoyed it too. There are some areas that you have to be really careful with young ones though to make sure they're not getting handsy with displays.

I LOVED IT! The people were amazing and so nice. The things that were displayed for us to see were really cool and interesting. My favorite part of it was when we went to see the little side show. He was funny and really cool, what he did was really cool. I HIGHLY recommend this place.

My boyfriend & I came here and wow what a great way to start our, “ keep Austin weird” journey! We decided to take the tour and it was only like $13 a piece. This included admission to the museum, a tour, and a little show at the end. The museum itself is not very long but it is packed with odd stuff I won’t spoil! Then we were taken by the tour guide and his adorable 3-legged dog. We walked the building and he told/showed us a lot of interesting things ( that I won’t spoil either) and we ended with a fun show with a lot of surprises that might make you squeal! He was an awesome tour guide, super funny and made our tour great. Also had a cute dog! He accepts tips at the end via cash, Venmo, etc in case you don’t have cash on hand.

Side note: I was scrolling through some reviews, many of the bad ones seem to be bad because they didn’t know what to expect so here are some tips for people wanting to go

If you go take the tour, the first part is a little area not very big of “freak show” type stuff like 2 headed animals and whatnot, then the tour guide will come and take you around the building to the Minnesota ice man, then to a room with wax figures of characters such as Frankenstein and a good photo opp with King Kong, then you will see the tour guides show. It is very entertaining, some may find it “gross” or too eclectic, if you do not like it or find any part of this, “satanic” or that your children cried and you found it offending then I suggest you grow a backbone.

name: Umlauf Sculpture Garden & Museum
address: 605 Azie Morton Rd, Austin, TX 78704, USA
reviews: The grounds are beautiful and peaceful;  UT campus has Austin's other concentration of Umlauf sculptures. The 2nd Sunday of the month is family day, free admission, sculpture seek-and-find by age, and musical or educational entertainment. Details on their website (some family days aren't on the normal schedule due to holiday overlap).

A very calm and relaxing place to indulge in nature and mesmerising sculptures..... People take their time looking at all the sculptures there....some sit on the benches for hours, painting or reading books.... They have a little waterfall near the entrance and you are able to sit at the top of it.....There is a little walkway and a canopy leading to it from the sculpture garden. It is a very romantic place for art or nature enthusiasts.....It's very close to a dog park and the Botanical garden....So if you are looking for a quieter place around the area, then this is your spot.

WOW
This artist really was at the height of his craft!!!
Beautiful. Inspiring. 
Filled w emotions.
Bring a friend!

What an intimate gem! Space, light, sculpture, water, flora breathe a collective life into the artistic and ambulatory  experience. I still walk the hallowed grounds of the Nelson in KC whenever I find myself there, but return to the Umlauf I shall , anytime
Interesting sculptures. Nice grounds. Not far from the botanical gardens. My wife and I have been there a couple times now when visiting Austin.

name: Austin Zoo
reviews: The animals all look happy and healthy. The staff is very nice. And it's very kid friendly. You know I've been to a lot of zoos and it's a smaller one, but I could of spent hours there. My niece and nephew got tired. But only spending 11.95 for a great experience priceless. And it looked like they are expanding. My point is the animals looked not stressed out I saw a mountain lion peacefully sleeping in a tree. We walked by the wolf exhibit and they started howling. And they have a petting and feeding the animals part that the kids loved. It great I'm going back again next week. If there was a ten star rating I'd give it that.

There is always a possibility for a close up encounter. Absolutely love the wildlife here. Foxes and wolves are by far my favorite of them all. It is a small zoo but they are here to protect and rehabilitate animals which I find far more important than bringing in animals for the sake of having them as an attraction.

They have a decent amount of animals. They have all kinds of monkeys, alligators, lions, tigers, parrots, wolves, sheep, llamas, peacocks, etc. It is very family friendly as well. This zoo saves animals. They had a few animals under vet care. The staff is very friendly and knowledgeable. My 10 and 13 year old kids loved it. It has a train for the smaller kids, an ice cream truck, gift shop, and you can feed the animals for an additional cost.

Such a great little zoo and something I can feel good about supporting because every animal is a rescue. There is a lot to see and the peacocks that roam free across the whole zoo are beautiful. Just a really cool experience all around

My family loves this zoo! It's not this huge place or grand. It is just a friendly and nice sized zoo. I feel this zoo does try to respect the animals and most are rescued. Child friendly and handicapped accessible.

name: Lake Travis Zipline Adventures
reviews:
This was one of the best times I’ve ever had in my life! So dang fun and the thrill was amazing. The boat ride there and back to the mountain was beautiful and relaxing. Our tour guides were the absolute best, they took their time with us up the hill and let us get plenty of breaks. All why telling us hilarious stories and jokes. Please request Lucy and Tonya, they are the best! 
 
Charlotte Listerine aka Shirley  lol

I had an absolutely amazing time! Amanda was a wonderful guide, she had us laughing and entertained entire time. She was very engaging with her entire group, and gave random factoid’s during the trip. She was also very considering of our entire group, whenever you go here definitely ask for Amanda!

Best Zipline experience I've had. Been Ziplining in California, Florida, and a few spots in TX now. This is the safest and most beautiful course I've been on. Two guides accompany you the whole way. They clip you in and make sure you get on, take off, stop, land, and dismount safely. No obstacles or rope courses to climb. Just hiking and zipping. It was also great to have adult guides. Joseph and Charlotte were extremely fun and professional at the same time. We (me and my 3 daughters ages 11, 13, and 15) all wanted to give them hugs when it was all done...but that would be awkward. Also...drinks for 21 and over.
No regerts 😊
Tonya & Lucy took my Wife, son,that's 8, and I on a Zip Tour today. Super fun. The staff was amazing. Highly recommend to all ages.

Beautiful scenery, great hike, extremely friendly staff, and very nice zip-lines. The price is a little too much and I would’ve really liked it if they used a better camera for taking pictures of the tourists. Most of their pictures were blurry. I still highly recommend the place and the experience.

name: Austin Nature & Science Center
reviews: I loved seeing the animals that were there and the beautiful plants. I would love to go there again. Its also a great place to bring your kids to learn a bit about wildlife. I recommend going, I'm sure others will love it as well. There are also some fun activities that you and your kids can do there as well.

Free to visit, but they have a little donation box in the visitor's center, so we left what cash and change we had. They have a lot of birds of prey as well as a raven and a bobcat. There are also reptiles and bugs. It's on like 80 acres, so they have some nice hiking trails to wander around. Great place to take children or go on a date.

A lot of free fun to be had, great place to take your kids. Multiple animal exhibits, plenty of scenery for family photos, and the Dino Pit will tire out the most energetic member of your crew. If you have a family, I highly recommend setting aside a few hours for a visit.
This is for kids and is not a museum. So it wasn’t what we expected. That being said we found an awesome hike out past birds of Prey!
Great for kids AND adults! Nice quiet and serene place to walk around and learn. My kiddos LOVED the dinosaur pit where you can excavate replicas of large fossils. So fun!

name: Hippie Hollow Park
reviews: The turn sneaks up on you if you aren't watching for it. Also, they only accept cash or check at the entrance for a pass. Come on a day with moderate overcast for perfect solace. There are two trails/ paths. Don't take the left one that goes up along the mountain if you have issues with cedar.  That path is full of the stuff. The path on the right next to the service entrance gate l follows the coastline by the water. There are also restrooms along the path (thank gawd). To get close to the water I think #8 is the best stairway to take along the trail.

My wife and I visit Hippie Hallow at least a few weekends each summer. It's a long drive from Dallas just to go there but we do anyway making a weekend of it and enjoying Austin night life.
The place is clean, it's safe, we've never been bothered. Of course there are some walkers with dark glasses kind of taking in the sights but that's understandable. My wife seems comfortable and I am as well. We have actually made some friends out there and shared the same tanning area.
It's a fun and relaxed place. It's always a good practice to be non judgemental as you'll see all sorts of body shapes and sizes. We usually carry a cooler with food and drinks, funny alcohol is allowed but you can not display it. Listen and be forewarned, it can be dangerous walking down to the Waters edge, notice I didn't say beach. It's very rocks and finding a flat spot can be a challenge. Just be careful, you do not want to fall down, especially in the buff!!
Thank you Austin Texas for allowing this to exist. Austin, the heart beat of Texas!!
Oh, there's and entry fee, and it does often reach capacity meaning you'll be turned away!! Get in early on a beautiful day.
Second time here and I love it. Water is cold as expected during January but the sun was bright and warming. Got some melanin charged!
Great place to tan. No lines. Water was warm. People were friendly. Will go back when weather is better. I invite everyone to come and be free in your own skin. Relax and enjoy yourself.

To truly understand yourself you must go into the wilderness completely naked in front of complete strangers to understand that your mind is the true enemy. Being nude is complete freedom & Hippie Hollow is the place to start.

name: Auditorium Shores at Town Lake Metropolitan Park
address: 900 W Riverside Dr, Austin, TX 78704, USA
reviews: We actually saw 2 fresh water otters there in the pond next to the Palmer Events Center which shocked us since we have never seen otters here in Austin. Also to have seen the otters there instead of the lakes here in town or swimming holes. I have lived here 32 years and I have never seen this before. I do hope that no one goes there and messes with them!

Went to the Texas Roller Derby Girls show  tonight at the Palmer Events Center. Always great craic,  that's " Gaelic "  for fun.  Tonight was the Holy Rollers. Vs  the Cherry  Bombs. The wifey , mother in law and friend had great night. Would recommend for a good night out. It is on the fringe side of Austin's  eclectic community so you see a great cross section of our wonderful city. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful landscape. Went to work out with a friend the people there are friendly polite and sharing. Big park and lots to do. The ppl there make you want to enjoy your time there. Visit and you will be glad you did!
Amazing facility with incredible views. Great parking with so many places to eat around the area. It's a wonderful place for photos, picnics, and just to sit and read a book.
Beautiful area. Great dog park. Clean walking trails. And most importantly Stevie Ray Vaughn.

name: Stevie Ray Vaughan Statue
address: 210 Ann and Roy Butler Hike and Bike Trail, Austin, TX 78704, USA
reviews: I visited Austin in April 2019 and spent a lot of time at the Stevie Ray Vaughan Memorial. He was one of the greatest musicians of the 20th century and certainly a tribute to the state of Texas. I love his music because  he played from his heart. In Stevie's own words, "I use heavy strings, tune low, play hard and floor it."
I enjoyed seeing this statue, but wouldn't suggest seeking it out unless you are a solid Stevie Ray Vaughan fan. Greetings from Austin, Texas, USA
Good spot see the Austin skyline and hike/walk around.
The memorial is set on the Colorado River with a picturesque backdrop of Austin. A fitting tribute for a Texas Blues Legend.

SRV is a staple of Texan culture and was a hell of a musician. The park itself is a great backdrop for a statue well worth seeing if you're a fan of the man. Make sure to pay close attention to the cool details (ie. the ring , earring, etc.)

name: Cathedral of Junk
reviews:
BE SURE TO CALL AHEAD AND RESERVE! This is his home in a private neighborhood and you must call ahead. Adult entry is $5/person. 

A must-see in Austin! Vincent, the artist, is welcoming and friendly. Had a great time wandering through corridors and up and down staircases, peering closely at conglomerations of knickknacks. Great photos, nostalgia, whimsical creations, and impressive structural creativity.
I visited a week ago with my kids, and they had a blast. We had fun exploring and can't wait to go back. It's a fun place to take out-of-town guests to give them the Austin experience.

A different way to spend an hour in Austin that isn’t eating tacos or drinking. Definitely a sight to behold, and a cool feat of human tinkering. Minus a star for the seeming  reluctance of the artist/owner to acknowledge the level of notoriety this exhibit has reached, and not yet setting up a simple website, or even just adding a few pertinent details on the google maps listing. Unless you read through multiple reviews, you wouldn’t know until arrival that the structure is located in the artist’s backyard, in a residential neighborhood. There is a faded hand-scrawled note on an old drum in the front yard that says “By Appointment Only” - extremely easy to miss. Luckily the owner was out attending to other guests when we arrived, so we apologized for showing up unannounced (though we had tried calling multiple times during our short 3-day trip and there was never an answer nor a machine message saying not to show up without a confirmed appointment) and paid a $5 donation before entering his back yard, where the structure is. The artist is a unique person, and has a way of speaking that can come off as pretty rude or blunt. It’s understandable: he views it as allowing random strangers to show up at any time and tour his backyard for a small donation. And as an outsider/visitor/google map peruser who stumbled across this “outdoor art gallery” listing with no website or hours or other info, I viewed it as this dude being a bit brash in his tone when you think you’re simply arriving to look at some public art. All this to say, I see both sides, and just think it would serve him (and purveyors of local art & culture) well to set some viewing hours, and a simple website link with an appointment plugin. So that’s my suggestion, and reason for docking 1 star. Other than that, yes it was cool & you’ll probably enjoy it. (And hey if you’re not super sensitive like me, you won’t get hurt feelings from his tone and you’ll REALLY enjoy it!)

Definitely an interesting art installation. It was an inviting place and lots of junk to see which was turned into artwork. I felt like some of the pieces had peaceful messages. I took my family to see the place and although they were a bit hesitant about seeing it, they ended up really enjoying it as well.
Such a cool experience! Vince is very talented and gracious to allow people into his own private property for this. Try to call ahead and park on the crossroads to reduce traffic at his house.

name: Lockout Austin
address: 1700 S Lamar Blvd Suite 327, Austin, TX 78704, USA
reviews:
It was really scary and anxiety inducing. That's the name of the game, though.

We were in a group yesterday or the day before with a trio of kids who were former DC interns getting together in Austin. There was one girl who was extremely impressive with the puzzles. She said I was admirable, but like, ethically. It had nothing to do with the puzzles. Generally good vibes. Hope she's doing well, wherever she is.
We had a great time. Fun staff and helpful. Played the enchanted chamber. Lots of fun. Would love to have a lockout in my town!
This was my first escape room and I was not to excited to go but everyone in our group had a blast I highly recommend.
So much fun. Puzzles were the correct hardness and everything worked out so well. I’ve done a few other escape rooms, this was the best. Watch out for Crazy Mike!!

Hands down the best place for a live escape room experience, since they have actors acting the prolog! Their bookings are not private, but they accept walk-ins a few minutes prior the beginning of the game and pretty much we never had anybody other than us in a room like that!Their themes are awesome and you can complete most rooms as a couple. They have limited hints, so make sure to ask them at the right time. My husband and I loved Cursed Ship. Great experience!

name: Mexic-Arte Museum
reviews:
Super small and not a lot of art to call a museum in my opinion. 7.00 just to walk a few feet.

The gift shop was nice and tons of cool items.

The staff was incredibly RUDE. The little girl at the gift shop register was miserable and unwelcoming. Not to just to our group, but others I witnessed. I noticed there's been other reviews about a girl in the gift shop being rude. Her daddy must own it, can't get fired and miserable cause of it. Just my guess, why else would they keep such bitterness on staff. I was embarrassed she was a representation of the Mexican culture at such a place that supposed to celebrate and educate on my roots. Shame.

A nice space with an interesting variety of work. When we went it was a collection of graphic art. I very much enjoyed the exhibition of  12" x12" works from local artists on a common theme that is used to fund their local projects. 
With a visit!

This place has more of a gallery feel than a museum you can even buy the art in the second half. It's worth noting that it's free on sundays and the day of the dead stickers in the gift shop features popular characters from every genre.

This museum caught my eye walking by, and I was blown away by the pieces inside. I loved how local art was displayed and highlighted. The themes were moving and spoke to me. As a native Texan and Latina, this experience was humbling and inspiring. Whatever walk of life you come from, please stop by and see what meaning you glean from this special gallery. Whether you're looking for beauty, emotion, or something else, you'll walk away with something important.
What a terrific museum.  I highly recommend Mexic-Arte Museum.  So many amazing print artists!    I can't wait to come back.

name: Texas Military Forces Museum
address: 2200 W 35th St building 6, Austin, TX 78703, USA
reviews:
A free museum in which you can spend a healthy 1-2 hours checking out all sorts of military items?  Sign me up!
Awesome place to check out tanks, planes, attire and so much more of what our armed forces (mostly, if not all, Army) utilize.
I really enjoyed the D-Day area.  Lots of great info!
Fantastic free museum. Definitely worth the visit. Lots of great history and some really fun interactive portions. And don't forget to check out the Jets and cannons on the parade grounds.

My boyfriend and I went here on a date. It was very cool and interactive as well. There was much too see, from planes, to trucks and tanks. We got too sit in a cockpit, and you also have the option to try on some Uniforms. So very neat all around. The historical sections are great for learning and visualizing everything that happened in historical wars or major events.
There was also a cute little shop for suvanears and gifts. This museum was probably the better part of that day in Austin.

They have a great array of informative exhibits from the different wars. There is a cool fighter jet that you can climb into for pictures, as well as full army uniforms for the kiddos to try on. They have tanks, wagons, and more. I think there may also be stuff to see outdoors but we went on a rainy day and stayed inside. It was cool and more importantly...free.
A wonderful place to go on the weekend or anytime! The exhibits are easy to follow and entertaining. My family and I have visited more than once, and I'm sure we will return.

name: Elisabet Ney Museum
reviews: This studio museum was amazing to explore.  Love Elisabet Ney and her husband's history. The studio she designed was equally impressive.  Her clay sculptures were beautiful,  including the last piece she  had worked on before she died, Prometheus! This place is a must for anyone visiting Austin. Architecture was incredibly designed and built by her, totally functional and resembled a  small castle.

Free to public..museum had docent (guides) to help you around or if you want to go alone cheat sheets.  I love the fact it's free and about a female artist that I didn't ever hear about before.  Please go to the web site and vote for them.  More of these hidden gems need to be saved.  No bathrooms..and staircases to climb.

Such a fun little museum. They have a lot original plaster casts and a couple marbles. The building and lot were awesome with secret doors and a bookcase door that we got to look at. The kids loved all the secrets. Nice little contemporary show of wall art in one room that is has rotating shows.
Awesome history and displays of art. Staff is very knowledgable , no question they can't answer. Great place to take kids who love art also.
The grounds and landscaping here are beautiful! It’s so nice to just walk around, especially on a warm spring day like today.

name: Mueller Lake Park
reviews: Super fun park where you can easily spend half a day. The field is perfect for lounging or pickup games and picnics. The lake is great for strolling around, and there is lots of wildlife like turtles, ducks, and fish. The playground is very fun, well maintained, and safe. Public restrooms are available just next to it so you'll never need to go far. In the spring the trees bloom making it the best time to visit, and in the weekend the best farmers market in the city  is next door. It's an overall great park that's worth multiple visits.

The farmers market is great on Sundays and the path is a great spot to walk your dog. If you have kiddos, there is a neat park and one of the restaurants new by has a play ground thing in there. My dog and I enjoy seeing all of the geese/birds at the pond.

I took my niece and nephew here for the day and they had a blast. My nephew ran around the lakes my niece couldn't get off the playground. It's a great place to spend on a Sunday with kids with family or with friends. Don't be surprised if you see a couple of dogs running around; they're usually friendly too. They have live music concerts, holiday events and almost anything else you can think of. The farmers market on Sunday is a must I highly recommend it to anyone in town even if you're just visiting

One of my favorite areas of Austin. I have spent many years in Mueller watching it quickly rise. The lake brings great energy and an abundance of animals scattered through out. 

Great environment to bring your kids and dogs to play. You can spend a whole day here with countless activities to participate in. They stock the lake with rainbow trout once a year where fishing is permitted.

As you can see I enjoy practicing yoga, as well as setting up photoshoots with my business here. 

If it’s a beautiful day outside I highly recommend checking out Mueller Lake Park.

This park is so clean and pretty. My husband took me out here for a walk and i really liked it. It was so peaceful even though there were many people. The air was fresh and even on a hot summer afternoon, it was breezy. You can do a picnic here while enjoying the lake view. It is also pet friendly. Its also nice to come pit here for a run.

name: Texas Memorial Museum
reviews:
Nice place it has 6 floors a nice variety of fossils & minerals. It's a great place to be with your family to see fossils minerals and even dissected animals. The stairs can be a little bit of a work out too if you are not used to walking much. The second floor is where the main entrance is and the first floor is underground.
They have a nice little shop which to be honest have ripoff prices because I'm not about to spend $15 dollars for a little rock. Overall it was a good experience.

Great state natural history museum accessible for all ages. The main entrance is the second floor which is a nice geologic exhibit that has an amazing skeleton of a Pterasaur dangling from the ceiling. The first floor (basement level) has a beautiful assortment of prehistoric skeletons that showcase life found in Texas before recorded history. It's a great museum for everyone.

Great spot for all ages! Their exhibits are well explained. The dinosaurs from Austin, Big Bend and around texas are amazing. This is an inspiring spot for kids who are interested in fossils, paleontology, geology and the natural world. There are even large fossils from around Austin!

One of the more underrated gems in Austin's weak museum scene. Not the largest museum out there, but they have a great collection of fossils, minerals and Texas wildlife exhibits on display, as well as opportunities to interact with scientists in those areas. Good place to pass an hour or two with the kids, especially for the price.

Our first time here and our 3 year old son really enjoyed it as did my husband and I. I see some complaints about how it used to be free but they charge now, the building is old and is only getting older and upkeep and salary (i.e. security guard and gift shop) is not as cheap as it used to be back in the day either. It was a well $19 spent for our little family. We were there for about an hour and a half.

name: Allens Boots
address: 1522 S Congress Ave, Austin, TX 78704, USA
reviews: I spent well over an hour trying on boots and getting assistance from Andrew. Spectacular selection of traditional boots, but not really riding or work boots. They were great about finding my size if I saw a style I liked. Since I was traveling, they shipped my boots to my house and I had them in 3 days! Great place, go find your perfect boot!

Loved this cute store! You can find boots, hats, belt buckles, bags, clothes and all sorts of cool things. Everything is good quality and the variety they have is unmatched. I would definitely recommend it if you’re in the market for some leather goods.

I very rarely get to come this way, and it's always a treat going to Allens. The amount of artfully crafted footwear at large ranges of pricing, including great sales, is a true sight. I had the opportunity to bring someone this time around who was mesmerized at the sheer amount and variety of beautiful boots, and got to relive the experience in their eyes. There's a boot for every style and personality, the staff is very cordial, attentive, and it's overall a great experience. Even if you're not planning on buying a pair, I thoroughly recommend a visit to this magical land that smells of leather and wood.

Where do I begin?!? So many gorgeous boots to choose from. Most importantly,  the grear selection and reasonable prices are even made better with the quality of boots offered. As if that was not enough,  the Stetson hat collection and belt/buckle selection is really good too. A must see in Austin.

I walked in here not expecting to find a boot that actually fit my foot, but ended up with a pair of luccheses on sale that fit perfectly. Noah was the best. He helped me so much and was very friendly and a pleasure to talk to. I loved my experience in this store and expect you will too.

name: Sculpture Falls
address: Barton Creek Greenbelt Trail, Austin, TX 78746, USA
reviews:
The hike down the hill of life is not bad, the hike back up after swimming is the challenge. Bring water, and a backpack if you want to bring anything else. Totes and other bags can make the hike more difficult. 

Water had warm and cool spots, warmer the further up stream you were. With it low like it is now, you could easily stand in most parts.
Beautiful place. Cristal clear water. Be sure to clean up after yourself after visiting this place so it can stay that way.

This is our absolute favorite swimming spot right now. Easy hike down, maybe 20 minutes. Be sure to have shoes for the water, rocks are very slippery. We bring a couple of lightweight camping chairs and sometimes our hammock. It's a beautiful spot and dog friendly!  Enjoy!!

Beautiful place with very shaded hiking trails. It’s beautiful no matter what season you go to visit there. The trails are pretty long but it’s worth the hiking. I always love to go after a rain because the creek and falls are full with water and it’s just an amazing experience. Lots of people go their to swim as well. It’s another hidden gems of Austin.
Lovely spot. Busy on nice days. Too many dogs off leash.

name: UT Tower
address: 110 Inner Campus Drive, Austin, TX 78705, USA
reviews: The major landmark of UT. Make sure to take a photograph of this iconic tower if you visit UT Austin. Extremely scenic place and well maintained.
I've always loved it and now I work in it. The people inside are as great as it appears on the outside. Built for rollerskating librarians with dumbwaiters to deliver books, what more do you want?
Loved the library, would like to have an information sheet about how to use the projectors in the discussion rooms
Historic University of Texas Austin Tower and observation deck. There’s fountain in front of it and a turtle pond behind it. The state building is facing towards it.

Such a lovely campus, the buildings are beautiful and the UT Tower, so historic.  It was so nice to take a slow drive all around the Tower and see it from all sides. It was 107° that day, so walking wasn't a option for me. Another 'Must See' here in Texas.

name: Austin Visitor Center
reviews: Love Austin just wish I had more than a day to spend there. So much to see. Highly recommend The Duck Adventure Bus Tour!

Open to air bus tryp in the city of Austin, the bus not only take you on the road tryp but also on the water. One tryp gives you two type of experience!! The drive of the Bus/Captain of the ship give a good commentary which gives the information about the city and make the tryp interesting and exciting. The tryp is arount 1hour and 15 minutes long and being you back to the starting point.
There is a sovinere shop in the center from where you can buy the memory of your tryp to Austin USA.
A very cozy visiting center in Austin. Great atmosphere and great service. I highly recommend!
Harrison is a great help and resource. I asked about lockers and he mentioned bag check, and was going to go out of his way to see if he could find lockers near by. What great staff!

This is a great place to stop and check in. Awesome knowledgeable people ready to give great advice about the city and awesome places to visit, eat, and drink!  Our tour met there as a starting point. But we got there a bit early and had a chance to peruse all of the amazing items. My group ended up deciding it was worth it to come back after our tour and buy some goods. Bottom line cool place to stop and cool off. Get info and even a cold water or soda to go with you.

name: Harry Ransom Center
reviews: Open to the public, the collections housed here are beautiful and intriguing. However, the limited exhibition space limits the scope of these collections. Also, it's focus on literary material limits it's appeal to many. The building itself was very clean and the staff were quite friendly.

Great literary and photographic displays. 
Friendly staff.
Beautiful space.

Absolutely fantastic repository. I was so impressed with the two photography exhibits up right now. The curators did such a great job. I don’t think I will forget them any time soon. The selections from the Arthur Miller papers were also very cool and I have to give props to the processing archivists for getting a collection of that size ready for researchers in two years. The staff here were also very friendly and helpful, which is sadly quite rare with rare book and manuscript repositories. It is definitely worth a trip to the HRC if you’re in Austin.

This is a must see while you’re in the Austin area. This museum is small but also free. They do except small donations. There’s a Frieda Khalid painting, the first ever photograph, and a Gutenberg Bible. An incredible amount of history in such a small space. The staff here were helpful and friendly. There are not large bags allowed. You do have free use of locked lockers. There is a small exhibit on at this time, which I assume rotates. There is no free parking for this building.
This place is always fun to visit. They have really well put together exhibits, but it's not overwhelmingly large. Plus it's free, so you really have nothing to lose.

name: The Contemporary Austin - Laguna Gloria
reviews: Lovely peacock sanctuary full of art and picturesque nature nooks. Located down the street from scenic Mt. Bonnell.

So worth it! The exhibits are so fun and interactive! Spend a beautiful day outside! Lots of parking. Pretty sure it’s free Tuesday. And if you buy admission you get admission to both museums: this on and the one on Congress.

I found out about the Place through some friends and I'm really glad I found it because has some pieces from some amazing artists. Would highly recommend this place to anybody looking to spend a few hours in the beautiful Park and as a tourist fell really welcoming into Austin plus the staff was really nice at the help desk.

Fantastic museum with low admission fees. They even participate in Bank of America's Museums on Us program. Friendly staff and the outdoor sculpture garden is initially confusing but once you orient yourself, it's pretty easy. Lots of cool and unique pieces. Worth a visit if you're in the area.

It's hard to beat an outdoor sculpture garden that's also on the water! Definitely worth a visit for the location itself. The art is quirky and fun, but definitely very modern. You can go into the house and see a few of the rooms on the bottom floor. Your ticket also gets you access to the Contemporary Museum on Congress.

name: The Contemporary Austin - Jones Center
reviews:
Close to UT and if you are hungry, they can accommodate. We took our son here after the marathon, and he ate all of his steak and the parts of the ample portions that my wife and I could not finish.
We all had different cuts of meat and all were excellent. The staff was very good also.

The curation of the exhibits was excellent and the staff were friendly. It was also not too crowded when I went during a Sunday afternoon, which was welcome. The gift shop, although small, had lots of interesting gifts with that local "Austin" flavor. Last but not least, ticket pricing is really affordable for people from most backgrounds.

We had an amazing experience here. The staff was extremely friendly and helpful. The art was very moving. For me especially “The Boundary of Life”. Many great artists work here! We enjoyed the day pass to the outdoor exhibit as well and was well worth it. I believe we only paid around $10 to get in which included the dual admission. Highly recommend to anyone and for all ages! Thank you for making our trip to Austin more memorable.
Cool modern art museum with a great city view from the rooftop. We will be visiting here often.
If I was on Food Network's "The Best Thing I Ever Ate," the The Contemporary Austin - Jones Center would be one of the places on my list. Can you say "raiment delicious"?

name: Jourdan-Bachman Pioneer Farms
address: 10621 Pioneer Farms Dr, Austin, TX 78754, USA
reviews: I was here because Austin's first Annual Witch Fest was being held there. The feel of the place made you want to dress old worldly. As the tiny hippy with me and her mom said...it was like a western in color....I had so much fun and the vendors were wonderful. I say it was a success.
Went for Witch Fest. Hope you host it again next year. The place is BEAUTIFUL. Need to take the kid to check it out on a regular day. Blacksmith work is wonderful. Love my new knife.
Really great place for a nice hike or a picnic. Bring sturdy walking shoes, drinks and snacks! Very small shop in front but they are often sold out of food

Came here for witchfest. Lovely people, great experience. Long lines at food booth but that is common sense with so many hungry people. Be prepared. 
I will come back. Definitely.

This farm is really cool. We were here for the Austin Celtic Festival. The place is a lovely venue. We weren't allowed to bring water in, probably because gin and vodka look the same. There were no places that we could find for refilling our drinking water after we had to dump them out at the gate. :'(

name: Willie Nelson Statue
reviews: So cool that Austin celebrates Willie with his own statute. It's close to the park by Austin City Limits. Worth the short walk.
That's cool I love willie.
Super cool. And he sits in from of Austin City Limits. Great venue for music. Legendary!
Statue of one bad mofo who brought the cowboys and the hippies together.
Meh... I like the Stevie Ray Vaughn statue better

name: Texas Capitol Visitors Center
reviews: My 8 year old daughter and I had a very enjoyable time visiting the Texas Capitol Visitors Center. The lady at the help desk was very informative, friendly and had excellent tips and advice for our time in the visitors center and the Capitol itself. We learned so much information about the Capitol. There is a kids page they can fill information out as they go along at the help desk with crayons. Upstairs there is a 2 sided, more detailed fill out sheet that my daughter and I used. We spent an hour and 1 half here easily. Right now in one of the rooms there is a Lego replica of the Capitol building. It's amazing!
